Yes, Leibniz's belief in rationality and order did extend to politics and government, and he did have a political philosophy. Like his epistemological and ethical beliefs, Leibniz's political philosophy is grounded in the belief in God's rational and intelligible creation.

Leibniz believed that a just and rational society could be achieved by establishing a system of government that was based on reason and designed to reflect the order and harmony of the world. He believed that the best form of government was one that was led by a wise and just monarch who governed for the common good.

Leibniz also believed in the importance of international relations and cooperation, and he advocated for the establishment of a European Union-style organization that would promote peace and prosperity through mutual understanding and cooperation.

Overall, Leibniz's political philosophy is based on the idea that reason and order should be the guiding principles of society and government, with the ultimate goal of achieving a just and harmonious society.
